reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed March 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The location of the Inn is great, just a few steps to the harbor on a very quiet one way street. We stayed in the Claiborne Room. The room was small and the bathroom was tiny. The sink in the bathroom is extremely small reminding us of an outdoor drinking fountain with little room to even wash your hands. The rain-head shower is also a small corner shower and the is no tub. The bathroom was obviously a closet turned into a bathroom. The room was clean but smelled like clorox and, not being able to open the windows, we could not get rid of the smell our whole stay. There was a pot of dead hyacinths on the dresser. We chose to eat at the sister inn, the Palmer House, for breakfast at a cost of $5 for each of us. The breakfast was adequate but not inspiring - grits, cold scrabbled eggs, bacon, sausage patties, canned peaches mixed with fresh strawberries, coffee, juice. Complimentary breakfast was offered at the Cabell House which was big boxes of cereal, bread, coffee and juice.
reviews.title: Great Location but uninspiring

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed February 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Randy, the innkeeper, was very pleasant. Her parents owned the house so she grew up there and was able to offer some dinner suggestions. However, we chose our own restaurant after checking a few of her top suggestions. We ate at Poogan's Porch (poogansporch.com) and enjoyed our meal and the friendly staff. We feel that you could get much more for you money someplace else.
reviews.title: Southern Charm !

likes.liked: — Quiet and Relaxing. Free parking. Great hospitality

reviews.text: My husband and I were delighted to have a weekend stay at the Cabell House for our 14th wedding anniversary. Not only are Randi and her husband very kind and gracious proprietors, but Randi is originally from the Charleston Peninsula, and grew up in this house she shares with the public via a B&B. If you enjoy learning about Charleston history Randi has many interesting stories and memories of Charleston since childhood. The home itself is clean, inviting and full of history and charm. If you are a true romantic or historian, you will love the ambience and atmosphere of this inn.
reviews.title: Beautiful B&B, mediocre service

likes.disliked: — The staff was nowhere to be found

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed February 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: In conclusion, we enjoyed our incredible stay at an inn that gave us a true feeling of experiencing Charleston the way it was back in time. The Cabell House is also sistered with another Battery located inn, and we enjoyed visiting that inn during the afternoon and having a glass of Pinot as we overlooked the Harbor and The Battery . We are planning on taking our children to experience Cabell house in the spring to enjoy the Battery. It is definitely southern charm at its best!
reviews.title: Major Disappointment

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed October 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: My sister and I stayed overnight at the Cabell House Bed and Breakfast in Charleston as part of a girls' getaway. I spoke with the proprietor, Randy, by phone when making my reservation and she was very friendly and said she looked forward to meeting us both. However, when we arrived at 3 pm, we were greeted at the door by the housekeeper. She showed us to our room, and noted that Randy was "in the back." She did not give us any further tour or information. We left for dinner and then came back to settle in for the evening. Despite an outdoor temperature of 51 degrees, our room thermostat was set at 60 and the room was actually 58 degrees. Needless to say, we were freezing! The thermostat was in a locked box, so that we were not able to make any changes. This was around 8 pm. My sister stuck her head out of the room and just happened to bump into Randy, who then very nicely changed the thermostat and went and gathered up some hot chocolate for us. The remainder of the evening was quite nice. The house is quite beautiful, a 19th century Charleston home that is only about 2 blocks from the battery. It was also very clean. The following morning, we had been told (by letter, prior to our stay--we never did receive any "orientation" from the staff) that breakfast was from 9 - 10:30 am. I had told Randy by email about a week prior that we would be eating there at the B&B and we told them again when we arrived (and it was marked in bright orange on my check in sheet). However, we left our room with our luggage at around 9:15 am and met Randy coming down in her robe--she said "I was trying to sneak by." My sister said that we wanted to come down and eat a quick breakfast before leaving. Randy seemed surprised that we were eating there and then reminded me that we needed to pay (even though I had already done so by credit card in advance). She then said she would get dressed and come down. However, a few minutes later, David (whose exact role there I'm unsure of) came down and helped us with breakfast. He was very helpful, though admittedly unsure of what he needed to do. The cereal that was available was all in open boxes that had been sitting on the sideboard for, it appeared, quite some time. Otherwise, breakfast was good. We then had to ask the housekeeper for out receipt in order to sign, as Randy had still not come downstairs, and we were ready to leave for the day. Overall, the facility was quite beautiful, but I would not choose to stay there again based on the service we received.
reviews.title: Tremendous!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed November 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Room was spacious, super-clean, furnished with lovely antiques, and was very comfortable. The bathroom was new and furnished with European-style fixtures, including a rain-shower head in the corner shower. The off-street parking was very nice to have since the home is so close to the battery. The host family is very friendly and offered use of their piazzas to guests. A special treat is the agreement Cabell House has with the Palmer House (Pink Palace) home. Cabell guests are invited to walk around the corner to the free wine/cheese at the Palmer Home and for $5 can have a hot southern breakfast. Continental breakfast is served at the Cabell.
reviews.title: Super room, so close to the battery, off-street parking!

likes.liked: — The room/home was so historical and beautiful - huge crown/case moldings, antiques, etc.
